channel.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
channel.description:
Hi. So I've been learning C++ the past couple weeks and in an effort to expand my knowledge, I'm going to combine what C++ I know with my experience creating private servers. The project will be fully open-source and should be cross-platform (currently only supports Windows). The goal is to make a server that supports 2000 players and multiple revisions.
[b][url=http://code.google.com/p/rs2pp/]Source Code[/url][/b]
It's still [i]very[/i] early in development, but I figured I would post it here in case anyone wanted to closely follow the progress or provide suggestions.
~Lin

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

Naming may be a bit bad, you’re right. But the concept can be expanded further. The ‘null position’ referring to Position(x,y,z); with all parameters being null. The item will not be processed upon tick. When a position is given, the item can be added to a queue and then the queue will process with the game tick and handle ground items accordingly. This way “GameItem” can hold all item configuration and data that is needed without ground item support, etc. there’s probably better systems to do this. It just sounds cute to me c:

As for the “npc being character being bad” I never said it was bad, just I didn’t like it. But I wasn’t thinking when I posted that part. Sorry for that.

Read full topic

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:19, topic:525649”]Could make a general GameItem entity to hold all item data: position, configs, definitions, name, etc blah blah, and then GroundItem subclass. GameItem will have a position set to null by default. And when you give it a position, it will become a ground item.

I don’t really like your you having npc as a subclass to character. Sounds confusing but meh. I do wish you the best of luck![/quote]GameItem is a bad name, and that’s exactly what Entity is. Why is Character bad? NPC stands for non-playing character. Both NPCs and players have update flags, animations, graphics, and all that stuff that I would have to repeat, which includes combat. And there’s no such thing as a null position lol.

Read full topic

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

Could make a general GameItem entity to hold all item data: position, configs, definitions, name, etc blah blah, and then GroundItem subclass. GameItem will have a position set to null by default. And when you give it a position, it will become a ground item.

I don’t really like your you having npc as a subclass to character. Sounds confusing but meh. I do wish you the best of luck!

Read full topic

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Uncalled, post:15, topic:525649”]Bump - about to take a look at the code. I like the sound of the NGI system, but, like you said, it’s probably been done before. Also is there anymore updates on this?[/quote]For some reason, 90% of the time, the server will crash due to an access violation index when the 18th player logs in. Sometimes it goes much higher into the hundreds and crashes randomly for an unknown reason. I’m trying to fix this.

[quote=“Mezzyscape562, post:16, topic:525649”]Lin can I lick your titties? Because I can’t express my love towards this any other way :)[/quote]Yeah sure.

[quote=“Vain_, post:17, topic:525649”]dislike your naming of ‘h’ for height, instead of z

also why Node -> Entity -> Character -> Player.
what about item/object entities and npcs?

(i know you haven’t added support for them, but do you plan to create a new sub-node class per object, or a new sub-entity?)[/quote]It’s habitual. H(eight) just seems to make more sense than ‘z’, since in 3D game development, z is used for depth. The nodes can be used in any NGICollection and ground items will be entities, since they are basically entities.

Node
-----Entity
-----Character
-----Player
-----NPC
-----Ground item

Read full topic

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“sspoke, post:5, topic:525649”]Check out

GitHub

HadynRichard/openrs

openrs - An open-source RuneScape emulator. The core is written in C, and all game logic/content in Python.

its runescape 317 server written in just C you could use some of the stuff pretty easy to rewrite to C++ and will speed up your development.[/quote][quote=“sspoke, post:13, topic:525649”]Here is another C++ runescape server on google code

https://code.google.com/p/c-plusplus-runescape-server/source/browse/#svn%2Ftrunk[/quote]Thanks, I appreciate it, but I’d like to write the entire server based on my own research and experience. This project is entirely for learning C++ after all.

So anyway, I wanted to let everyone know I haven’t quit this project (that would be pathetic :P). Development is very slow because of how little C++ I actually know. But, finally after several hours of pulling my hair out and dealing with annoying linking errors, I got logging in and adding players down. I had to fix quite a few things, like my buffer reading methods and some things for the node storage.

For those who are curious, here’s how things (should) work. Node -> Entity -> Character -> Player. NGICollection -> NodeStorage -> PlayerContainer. NGI stands for “no-gap indexable”, which is basically a fancy array I came up with (I’ve never heard of it, but I’m sure it’s been done before) that you can add and remove elements to without it resizing and worrying about gaps. It’s like a linked list but unsorted and you can index it. Nodes have what is called an NGI Index, which is its position in the NGICollection. The NodeStorage is basically the NGICollection but with a bitmap of all the nodes inside of it. It’s worth noting it’s set with a specified index (entity index) and not the ngi index. There is no bitmap for the ngi index because of the “no-gap” part of the collection. When a node is removed, the last node in the collection is moved to the empty spot and its ngi index is changed. To get the next available ngi index, one would just get the amount of nodes in the collection. The only thing left storage-wise is a list of player indexes and their corresponding ngi indexes, which should be pretty easy to implement.

So, why all these confusing storage methods? It’s simple (well in all actuality its a pain in the ass and hard to keep track of). The NGICollection, like I said, is like a list that never has any gaps or resizing, which makes it really fast and easy to iterate through when it comes time for updating or something (O(n)). The bitmaps, like I said, allow for fast lookups with player indexes. The reason these have to be different is because the player index is determined as soon as the client logs in and even though there is a packet that can change it, I think it would cause problems. I need to add the table of entity indexes and their corresponding ngi indexes because when packets are sent and use the entity index, I would have to iterate through every entity in the collection to see if the index matched the specified one.

I think this is coming along quite well. It’s quickly become what seems like a confusing nest, but it should be fast. Also I think I’m going to drop the multi-revision compatibility. It’s very annoying to implement and I don’t see many benefits. Besides, it can always be ported.

Read full topic

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:8, topic:525649”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=644390.msg4336025#msg4336025 date=1374382643]
What ever happened to RuneEmu?
[/quote]I don’t know what that is.

Thank you for all the support so far. I got some basic stuff down like a good start to the data buffer and the entity hierarchy up to the player (it goes Node -> Entity -> Character -> Player). Tomorrow I should be able to get some work done on actually handling connections. I’m going to only write the server to support the 317 protocol, but the way I write it should allow it to be expanded to support any revision. I just don’t have that sort of motivation to actually add separate revisions.[/quote]

RuneEmu was a very old server written in C++
http://trac.assembla.com/RuneEmu/browser/trunk

Read full topic

item.title: RS2++ - Open-source C++ Server
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:7, topic:525649”]What ever happened to RuneEmu?[/quote]I don’t know what that is.

Thank you for all the support so far. I got some basic stuff down like a good start to the data buffer and the entity hierarchy up to the player (it goes Node -> Entity -> Character -> Player). Tomorrow I should be able to get some work done on actually handling connections. I’m going to only write the server to support the 317 protocol, but the way I write it should allow it to be expanded to support any revision. I just don’t have that sort of motivation to actually add separate revisions.

Read full topic
